summary: This is an FBI 302 report documenting the interview of a corrections officer who worked at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York during the shift when Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell. The officer describes the staffing and count procedures in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) and expresses shock at Epstein's death. The interview ends abruptly when the officer is shown a picture and requests a lawyer, after which his cell phone is seized pursuant to a search warrant.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found unresponsive
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The corrections officer was working the 12am-8am shift in the Special Housing Unit (10 South) when the call came over.

events.title: Interview of corrections officer
events.description: A corrections officer from MCC was interviewed by FBI and OIG investigators at the U.S. Attorney's Office in SDNY regarding the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, New York
United States Attorneys Office (USAO), Southern District of New York (SDNY), 1 St. Andrews Plaza, New York, New York
keyFacts: A corrections officer stated that inmate counts in the Special Housing Unit (10 South) should always be a 'double staff count' and that he would not do a count without a partner.

The officer expressed shock at Epstein's death, stating Epstein 'was supposed to be watched more closely' and that rounds 'should have been conducted regardless of whether Epstein had previously been on suicide watch or not.'
The interview was terminated when the officer was shown a picture and stated 'he wanted a lawyer.'
The officer's personal cell phone (a Motorola G6) was seized by the FBI pursuant to a search warrant issued by SDNY, but he refused to provide his passcode.
The officer voluntarily stated, 'I want to be clear, I never brought stuff into the jail or allowed stuff in. I never did that,' after requesting a lawyer.
